frontmatter.title: Images, Figures and Videos
frontmatter.description: MyST Markdown allows you to create images and figures in your documents, including cross-referencing content throughout your pages.
frontmatter.subject: MyST Markdown

children.value: Markdown can be used to include images and figures in your documents as well as referencing those images easily throughout your website, article or paper.
The simplest way to create an image is to use the standard Markdown syntax:
Using standard markdown to create an image will render across all output formats (
, etc). However, this markdown syntax is limited in the configuration that can be applied beyond
There are two directives that can be used to add additional information about the layout and metadata associated with an image. For example,
and allows you to cross-reference this in other parts of your document.

```{figure} https://github.com/rowanc1/pics/blob/main/sunset.png?raw=true
:label: myFigure
:alt: Sunset at the beach
:align: center

Relaxing at the beach üèù üåä üòé
```
notebook cell outputs as images or figures

Subfigures can be created by omitting the directive argument to figure, and having the body contain one or more images or figures.
These will be numbered as
We saw some great things on our trips this year to Banff, Canada üá®üá¶ and San Francisco, USA üåâ.
You can also cross-reference either the whole figure
. Each subfigure is given an implicit reference that matches the figure label with a suffix of their letter, for example, a figure with label
the two subfigures can be referred to as
, that label will be used instead of the implicit label.

:::{figure}
:label: my-figure
:align: left

(my-figure-fruit)=
![Here is some fruit üçè](https://github.com/rowanc1/pics/blob/main/apples-wide.png?raw=true)

![My vacation pics! üèù](https://github.com/rowanc1/pics/blob/main/ocean-wide.png?raw=true)

Some pictures of fruit and the ocean!
:::

See [](#my-figure-fruit) for the fruit, and [](#my-figure) to reference both subfigures.

children.alt: .svg is supported by web-browsers and is not further optimized or rasterized. When exporting to \LaTeX and PDF the images are translated to .pdf using inkscape or as a fallback to .png using imagemagick. Microsoft Word requires the .png export.

For example, if you had the following two files:

myvideo.mp4  <-- A video of something
myvideo.png <-- A frame of the video as an image
Then you could link them both with:
output, the video will be used, and when you build a
output, the image will be used.
